articles.headline: Death of Senator Places Christie in Difficult Spot
articles.snippet: Frank R. Lautenberg’s death has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the chance to give away a Senate seat, but the decision is fraught with pitfalls.
articles.abstract: Frank R. Lautenberg’s death has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the chance to give away a Senate seat, but the decision is fraught with pitfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death of Frank R. Lautenberg on Monday has left Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey with the kind of opportunity that politicians usually covet: the chance to give away a seat in the United States Senate. But the decision is fraught with pitfalls, none bigger than having to choose between improving his party’s fortunes in Washington and furthering his own political ambitions at home.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger, Jeremy W. Peters and Kate Zernike

articles.headline: Ford Showing Its Vigor as Industry Recovers
articles.snippet: Ford and Chrysler reported double-digit overall gains, with Ford’s F-Series trucks jumping 31 percent and Chrysler’s Ram brand rising 24 percent.
articles.abstract: Ford and Chrysler reported double-digit overall gains, with Ford’s F-Series trucks jumping 31 percent and Chrysler’s Ram brand rising 24 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades in Detroit, there was a clear pecking order among automakers: General Motors sold the most cars in the United States, followed by Ford Motor Company and then the Chrysler Group.

articles.headline: U.S. Cites Phone Calls in Apple Pricing Case
articles.snippet: The government presented evidence that executives of big book publishing companies discussed raising e-book prices at Apple’s behest before the introduction of the iPad.
articles.abstract: The government presented evidence that executives of big book publishing companies discussed raising e-book prices at Apple’s behest before the introduction of the iPad.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States government said on Monday that there were 100 phone calls among top executives of the publishing industry in the weeks leading up to Apple’s introduction of the iPad in 2010, when they had to decide whether to sign on to a deal with Apple that would raise the prices of e-books.

articles.headline: A Paean to Forbearance (the Rough Draft)
articles.snippet: James Agee’s unpublished 1936 article for Fortune about Alabama sharecroppers is being released on Tuesday as a book, “Cotton Tenants: Three Families,” with Walker Evans photos.
articles.abstract: James Agee’s unpublished 1936 article for Fortune about Alabama sharecroppers is being released on Tuesday as a book, “Cotton Tenants: Three Families,” with Walker Evans photos.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1936 Fortune magazine’s editors assigned a relatively unknown and disgruntled staff writer named James Agee to travel to Alabama for the summer and chronicle the lives of sharecroppers. When Agee returned, he was inspired by the subjects he had met and lived with, but frustrated by the limitations of the magazine format. His subjects, he argued, warranted far more than an article.

articles.headline: A Tale of Wall St. Excess
articles.snippet: A former trader traces his rise and descent in “The Buy Side,” a memoir about the underbelly of big-money, fast-paced hedge funds.
articles.abstract: A former trader traces his rise and descent in “The Buy Side,” a memoir about the underbelly of big-money, fast-paced hedge funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: Turney Duff, former stock trader, recovering cocaine user and first-time author, stepped out the front door of his new home, the ground floor of a modest split-level house in a sleepy Long Island neighborhood.

articles.headline: Behind the Rise in House Prices, Wall Street Buyers
articles.snippet: Homes in struggling markets are being snapped up by big investment companies, shutting out regular buyers and creating concern about soaring prices.
articles.abstract: Homes in struggling markets are being snapped up by big investment companies, shutting out regular buyers and creating concern about soaring prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time the housing market was this hot in Phoenix and Las Vegas, the buyers pushing up prices were mostly small time. Nowadays, they are big time — Wall Street big.

articles.headline: Wall Street Transfixed by SAC Deadline
articles.snippet: A quarterly deadline for investors to withdraw money from the troubled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was the talk of Wall Street on Monday.
articles.abstract: A quarterly deadline for investors to withdraw money from the troubled hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was the talk of Wall Street on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of the day Monday, a report about the investor exodus at the hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors was the most-viewed article on the Bloomberg data terminals that permeate Wall Street trading floors.

articles.headline: A Dispute Over Restrictions in a U.S. Auction of Airwaves
articles.snippet: The suggestion that some auction participants could get favored treatment in a spectrum auction has spawned a dispute.
articles.abstract: The suggestion that some auction participants could get favored treatment in a spectrum auction has spawned a dispute.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the mobile high-speed Internet market, the Obama administration believes it may be necessary to limit competition in order to promote it.

articles.headline: Promising New Cancer Drugs Empower the Body’s Own Defense System
articles.snippet: The drugs work by unleashing the immune system to attack cancer cells, much as it attacks bacteria or other foreign invaders in the human body.
articles.abstract: The drugs work by unleashing the immune system to attack cancer cells, much as it attacks bacteria or other foreign invaders in the human body.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The early success of a new class of cancer drugs, revealed in test results released here over the last several days, has raised hope among the world’s top cancer specialists that they may be on the verge of an important milestone in the fight against the disease.

articles.headline: As Turks Challenge Their Leader’s Power, He Tries to Expand It
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is facing his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, and he seems little inclined to change his approach.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is facing his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, and he seems little inclined to change his approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — After days of demonstrations that have presented Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan with his worst political crisis in more than a decade of power, the Turkish leader responded on Monday with a supremely confident flourish: he simply turned his back and left, boarding a plane to start a four-day good-will tour of Northern Africa.

articles.headline: Elite in China Molded in Part by Tiananmen
articles.snippet: The immersion of today’s leaders of China in the political experimentation that preceded the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989 raises the question of whether they will be open to new ideas and discussion.
articles.abstract: The immersion of today’s leaders of China in the political experimentation that preceded the Tiananmen Square crackdown in 1989 raises the question of whether they will be open to new ideas and discussion.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For four days, more than 400 of China’s brightest political minds gathered in smoke-clouded halls at a Beijing hotel, vigorously debating the nation’s future.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: When Billionaire Sets Rules, It’s an Exclusive Race
articles.snippet: An expensive new requirement has led to a dearth of contestants at the America’s Cup, and San Francisco leaders are raising doubts about the race’s benefits for the city amid lagging interest.
articles.abstract: An expensive new requirement has led to a dearth of contestants at the America’s Cup, and San Francisco leaders are raising doubts about the race’s benefits for the city amid lagging interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Victory in the America’s Cup of 2010 gave Larry Ellison, the tech titan who had spent hundreds of millions of dollars trying to capture sailing’s ultimate prize, the right to set the rules for this year’s regatta.

articles.headline: Obama Orders Regulators to Root Out ‘Patent Trolls’
articles.snippet: The president, in a series of executive actions, asked the patent office to take steps to block frivolous lawsuits filed by so-called patent trolls.
articles.abstract: The president, in a series of executive actions, asked the patent office to take steps to block frivolous lawsuits filed by so-called patent trolls.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One company threatened to sue 8,000 coffee shops, hotels and retailers for patent infringement because they had set up Wi-Fi networks for their customers. Another claimed that hundreds of small businesses were violating its patents by attaching a document scanner to an office computer system. One claimed rights to royalties from anyone producing a podcast.
